Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of a Multimode Spectrophotometer by Elon University to Enhance Undergraduate Research and Teaching in Chemistry and Biochemistry.
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program, Professor Victoria Moore from Elon University and colleagues Karl Sienerth and Kathryn Matera will acquire a multimode quad-monochromator plate reader spectrophotometer. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research training and education, especially in areas such as (a) peptide aggregates; (b) protein-protein binding; (c) biochemical changes to mitochondria during apoptosis; and (d) quantitative measurements of environmental and explosive compounds.

This award will provide a multimode spectrophotometer to make absorbance, fluorescence and luminescence measurements on various samples. These are standard spectroscopy techniques used to assay small volumes of solutions in chemistry and biochemistry. Reactions can be followed and quantities of materials determined. This acquisition will provide a basic instrument for current biochemistry and chemistry research by faculty and undergraduate students. Students will be trained to use the most up-to-date assays and technologies which they will encounter after graduation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the purchase of a multi-mode plate reader for use in teaching and research in a chemistry department at a primarily undergraduate institution. The grant money was used to purchase said machine, in addition to supplies utilized for its operation. The aquisition of this plate reader supported infrastructure and enhanced the research capabilities of the chemistry department. Furthermore, its use augmented the instruction faculty delivered to undergraduate chemistry and biochemistry majors.

Two seperate laboratory classes incorporated the plate reader, Advancced Biochemistry Lab and Instrumental Analysis Lab, both of which are upper level chemistry courses in the chemistry department. Over 75 undergraduate students thus far have received instruction about the technology the plate reader uses as well as in the use of the machine. After initial instruction, students then utilize the plate reader to collect data. Training these students allows them to be exposed to state-of-the-art technology in the chemistry and biochemistry fields, thereby enhancing their education and preparation upon graduation.

Four seperate research laboratories also used the plate reader to aquire data in different projects. The PIs of these labs and their undergraduate students programed different assays, collected data, analyzed data, and reported their findinings in multiple presentations at disciplinary meetings, Honors Theses, as well as published 3 peer-reviewed papers. 

The positive impacts of this project will continue for many years beyond the 3-year funding period of this grant.
